'Pikes Peak' (originally 'Pike's Peak') is a mountain in the Front Range of the
Rocky Mountains within Pike National Forest, 10 miles (16 km) west of
Colorado Springs, Colorado, in El Paso County in the United States of America.

Originally called "El CapitÃ¡n" by Spanish settlers, the mountain was renamed
Pike's Peak after Zebulon Pike, Jr., an explorer who led an expedition to the
southern Colorado area in 1806. The Arapaho name is 'heey-otoyooâ' ("long
mountain"). {{Cite web
| title = Arapaho Place Names work = Arapaho Language Archives, University of
| Colorado at Boulder accessdate = 2012-07-18 url =
| http://www.colorado.edu/linguistics/csilw/archives/Placenames0626.xml
}}

At , it is one of Colorado's 54 fourteeners, mountains
that rise more than above mean sea level, and rises above the city of Colorado
Springs. Pikes Peak is a designated National Historic Landmark.
